posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

Previous Thread: >>6457865

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460785
I think that the process of painting/drawing a pictore is so different from prompting that you have to doubt if the people labelling themselves as "ai artists" right now would ever have gone through the trouble of learning how to draw properly without ai. Sure, some of them were trying to learn it at some point but so were a lot of other people who never had the patience to actually become good at it and eventually ended up moving on to other things. Promting just happened to what this partucular group moved on to but I seriously doubt many of them would have become "proper" artists if not for ai. They'd more likely just be playing video games or shitposting on reddit instead.

In the end, comparing drawing to prompting is like comparing someone taking a photo of a landscape to someone making a painting of that same landscape. Sure, they might come up with results that look similar but the process in itself is so different that one person would most likely not enjoy what the other is doing and vice versa. Are there some people who like both painting and photography? Sure, just like some will combine the two into a single artwork but there are also plenty of people who only enjoy one of the two and there's nothing wrong with that. It's simply two different ways to produce an image.

Not saying this to defend ai by the way, I still think the way it was produced and marketed is shady as fuck and I'm all for regulations to stop these schizos from creating their AGI dystopia. But I also think saying "why would you prompt if you can just learn how to draw" is disingenuous in a way, since most of the current prompters likely would never have learned how to draw anyway, with or without the existence of ai

Yeah, art is not a fucking horse and carriage. And in the case of disruption (photography) the role of the artist was reactionary, not bending over for the tech. Artists don't like to think of themselves as reactionary, but all those modernists (the ones /ic/ love to shit on) were boldly reacting to technological change.
>not all these disruptions were good?
No not all disruptions are good. Technological progress is not always 'progress'. Thanks to being raised on smartphones and social media the zoomers I work with are social retards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

Either find what you like drawing, get out of a comfort zone, experiment by fucking with different media/styles, or find something else entirely. Even if you might be good at it, it may still not be a fit because you don't like it. For example I'm great at the physical and mental aspects of my work, but there's so much bureaucratic paperwork horseshit associated that it sucks all joy I might have from it.

Art as a profession is something one should take joy in otherwise while the skill may remain, the soul goes away. Art as something for yourself doesn't need to worry about it, and if you don't enjoy it, much as I hate the word, you're just being a poser for likes and (You)s.

Do what you love anon. Draw what you love, draw who you love

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451437
Practice, simple as.
When I did go to an art school for a bit, I went in expecting to be amongst titans, but I still ended up being a big fish in a small pond, mostly because I've been drawing for longer than most have been alive there.
You just gotta do it over and over again, until eventually you can internalize steps and externally "skip" them, so instead of doing the rough skeleton, your able to go straight to rough details and all of that.
At one point I just went hard mode and exclusively used ball point pen to draw, so no pencil roughs to erase later, just try to make it look good in one go, results turned out to about pic related.
Just practice practice practice

Can't be fucked to read all the drama stuff but your linework could use some improvement.

Here is some advice:
-The piece is pretty chicken skratched, I would make the linework red and then draw over it again untill I get a clean result.
(go to the layer in krita and press the checker thing, get your brush to 50px or something and just draw over the linework)

>How do I make it clean without looking completly soulless
there is some advice on youtube but beyond practice (drawing more finished pieces) idk how to help you , hopefully some anons here know better than me here.

-Improve perspective
Unsure if this is out of:
lazyness (knows how to but cannot be fucked to measure it)
If that is the case Measure your pespective more thoughly , set up ground planes , draw the entire volume to make sure its not noclipping into anything , draw the foreshortening using vanishing points instead of just eyeballing it.

lack of knowledge (does not know how to measure it)
Learn perspective. (perspective made eazy is a good start)

Anyways problem that jumps out is:

-She appears to be standing at the ledge of some sort of wall based on her "staight towards the viewer" leg but based on the hand she appears to be standing on flat ground.
The only reasonable explination would be that she is standing on top of some sort of weird corner wall that you have not bothered to draw , but most viewers will just imagine flat ground.
(drawing a ground plane/the wall in question would have prevented this)

-The second would be proportions , the "staight towards the viewer" leg appears too short if its supposed to be "dangling from atop" and even fucking worse if this was supposed to be on flat ground. (where is her foot)
(you can fix this by drawing circles in perspective , the center at the joint and the radius is the length of the limb , this is a pretty annoying method so I only use it when I really struggle with something)

-The third is line continunty on the arms and sleeves

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6466675
>>6466675

I grew up mixing realistic with manhwa and manga. Drawing that till memory so when I came across Shinkiro and love his way of rendering. I just kept combining as I go, for me it's a happy middle ground where I can adjust it to look more anime or more western comic like.

Drawn in PhotoShop with base skin tone foundation, then marking out the features with a graduation of soft darker tone. When it's ok, I'll start going in with bold lines and divide the layers, hair >face > body > bg and continue to finalise.

>>6462203
>What if the artist only intended to make porn and I approach it purely academically.
You can approach anything academically, but it still won't make it not what it actually is.

And since you want to approach it academically, you should start asking critical questions:
>What is the picture illustrating?
>What is the reason of existence of the picture?
>Does the picture objectively have any other message/artistic expressions besides what it is visually portraying and appealing to?

It is fine if one draws porn for a living, but it is nothing more than kitsch and a service; the purpose of erotic imagery is to appeal to and engage with the most basic instincts.
It is art only visually and practically, but artistically it is not real art, it is a consumer product.

Like everything else there's grey areas.
Robert Crumb is a good example. Much of his work could be considered pornographic, but it has artistic merit. I consider him one of the greatest artists of the 20th century (and critics like Robert Hughes agree).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I think there exists a highest ideal. Like making a sword, you beat and hone and polish as many imperfections out as you can. You form it to be balanced, you take scientific care in materials used, to ultimately create something that's both elegant and functional. Rules govern what goes into it. Is it fit to stab? To slash? To parry? Do you want to protect the hand? Is it going to see the ocean where any brasswork might resist corrosion better? People are way more complex and each instinct bears much more examination. And rules apply just the same there, attached to all the same laws of physics as bad metallurgy. I don't think Sasha Grey.txt can be argued with as the highest ideal, and I think the further from that ideal is a simple matter of incorporating more flaws which introduce more problems. Porn being so far removed from the ideal that promoting it could be considered downright hateful at the worst, and simply never fully in good faith at best.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP here, since you keep asking I'll post my art.

I designed this poster for a squat project I took part in, we squatted a big old abandoned military building and lived there for some time during winter with the mission of hosting an underground psychedelic rock concert, the first one was in anoher country and it was a success but that's another story.

The poster itself has a distorted version of the building itself.
The strawberries represent the symbol of the town of viljandi which is strawberries, it was adopted from a famous painting from the town called strawberry eaters.

We got together with students of the local cultural academy, I designed this poster based on the ideas by people who were interested in this project

The character playing the guitar is a homage to Gong, a british psychedelic funk band that is a large inspiration for us, the strawberry theme is also partially inspires by our bassist who would sometimes wear a strawberry hat.

The strawberry wizard is a gong inspired character we came up with.

It has a few funny details besides previously mentioned things.

This poster was drawn in the abandoned house.

The text includes quotes of funny reactions to the previous poster.

It doesn't have colours because the only colourized version was deemed not good enough and I was meant to do the colours again before taking it to the printers the concert got cancelled only a couple of weeks before the concert was supposed to take place so the final colourized version was never made.
The people who bought the building had no idea about this and they thought it was cool so they asked the police to take a picture of us in front of the two posters which I gifted them.

A colourized version exists but I consider the original sketch here much better.
I only draw comics, I rarely draw anything unrelated to my comic.

My point here is that art has a purpose and porn is an excuse for creatively lazy and passive people to give context to their drawings

Continued,

This is what I'm working on right now.

The only reason why I consider this artis beacuse it's a comic book page and the artistic context behind it is my writings.

I haven't sketched out the other panels at all yet but just to give an example if I just drew this space station and left the drawing like this at bestit would be just a concept or a drawing with no artistic context.

I could draw anytime I wanted but I choose not to because to call my drawings art I need context.

If you drew a hyperrealistic portrait of a photo of walter white at home to post it online for likes it would not be art.

If you went outside and sat down to spectate life and saw a hobo throw up and getting arrested, even if it looked poorly drawn it would be more artistic than the soulless walter white drawing.

That's my point.

Artistic energy is limited, context is the fuel of art.

We can produce unlimited amounts of drawings but art is limited.

You can never create renaissance art because renaissance happened, it's restricted to its context.
If you made a portraid that was technicay better than renaissance art it would still be worth less since it doesn't have the cultural or historical context.

In fact many renaissance paintings are mediocre as illustrations by today's standard but their artistic value is priceless.

What is unlimited is worthless, anyhting valuable is limited.

This is how I see art.

To all you porn artists.

Go outside, get ideas, experience life and reality and then use that artistic fuel you've gathered.

"original, unique art does not exist"

Correct, that's why we must rely on context and not simply the visuals.

Only context can be absolutely unique.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464093
Basically
>choose image you want to copy
>draw a grid over it
>draw a proportionally identical (scaled up or down, or 1:1) grid on the paper or canvas you wish to copy the image to
>begin your copy
Basically having grid makes it easier for your eye/brain/hand to copy exactly what you see, since you're just copying several small images, each of which sits inside of a small square, without having to worry about the overall proportions of the subject or getting "lost" in what you're looking at.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464093
>>6464126
if you understand better visually, here's a grid drawing i did

i'm not going to pretend like i know what i'm talking about but i think that the point is to help measure proportions on a smaller scale
instead of having to measure proportions using a very complex image with nearly no reference point, the grid makes it much easier to be able to get the proportions down with much more accuracy than if you had done the drawing freehand

by forcing yourself to focus on individual squares rather than an entire image, you basically limit the chances of failure which helps motivate you and at least make it seem like you're improving when you do start to get better
you can technically start off by just straight-up copying but if you're someone who is easily de-motivated, like myself, starting from the absolute basics will be helpful
the point would of course be to remove the grid altogether to be able to copy with accuracy without a grid

i believe other artists use it to be able to get an image down onto their paper with the most accuracy as possible which isn't exactly related to the reason that i am using it for

>>6463701
You're not supposed to draw primitives over the original image, you're supposed to draw it on the side. It takes longer to perfect, but that's how you learn. That way, you could still create the image (or an informed approximation of it) without needing it there. That's how you test your ability to communicate with images, rather than words.
Telling people that it's okay to trace will create bad habits that they'll fall back on, and therefore limit or slow down their potential.

Tracing really has no place in serious art, hence why only hacks profess it.
Even Norman Rockwell, who used projection image slides from photographs, expressed disgust at his reliance on it all, with his final works being much higher in quality as they were not constrained by it.

The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:

>>6449929
It's very good for making manga (page by page format) and webtoons (scrolling format).
Pretty much every professional that makes manga digitally uses it.
It has all the tools you need and the free assets store has a ton of stuff to make the creation process even easier like premade speech bubbles, manga backgrounds, effects brushes, 3d models and so on.
My only gripe with clipstudio is that the lettering system is so barebones that it hurts.
It gets the job done but it does feel very clunky doing your lettering in clipstudio.
I've only made comics in paint tool sai before and compared to that clipstudio is so much better.
Also there's a ton of tutorials on the creation process both official and by fans on youtube.
Just buy it on a sale.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6454002
I have only looked at the chapters so I can't comment on the writing.

I really like the composition and artstyle even though it's pretty simple and scratchy.
It seems to fit the atmosphere quite well.

You should really think about using proper speechbubbles or if you want to keep the uniqe speechbubbles you currently use then please use a better font.
Your current font makes it look like those old scanlations of manga.
Lettering is just as important as art and composition.
Blambot.com has a lot of free and good looking comic fonts for dialogue and effects. Blambot even lets you use these fonts commercially for prints and stuff if you're an indie artist.

I can also see you're structuring the panels like a manga or comic page.
You don't have to do this on webtoon because of the infinite scrolling webtoons have.
Take advantage of this feature and give your panels more breathing room and space between each other.
It feels very crammed and overwhelming as it currently is. Remember, there are no pages on webtoons. There's just one very long page pretty much.
Look at how popular webtoons are placing their panels.
You can do a lot of unique and fun paneling on webtoon that you couldn't do with a traditional page-to-page layout.

Also think about using more differently shaped panels.
It's fine as it is right now but it might become boring or samey seeing the same rectangle panels as you create more chapters.


Overall it looks good and promising. Godspeed anon!

>>6454002
I read the full thing. I though it was great, main thing I dislike is the dialogue. You should change the font, have speech bubbles, and also just go over everything to remove unnecessary lines, and edit forced lines. I'm also working on a comic, and it's definitely a challenge to make dialogue seem natural and not cringe-inducing. Try and act out the interaction in your head, and ask yourself if it would be like that in a real life interaction. Also keep in the mind that the character's personality plays a role in each interaction (If you haven't done this already, you should write down a document for yourself that includes your character's personality, motivations, fears, etc..) And another thing to keep in mind is that not everything has to be vocalized.

I found it weird how this main character knows English well when she was abandoned as a little kid, I think she should be more mute (Or maybe you could make her dialogue have a purposefully limited choice of words.) And like the other anon said, it should be explained how she built an entire house by herself, knows how to cook, and how she has money.

Overall I thought this was pretty cool and I'm looking forward to your revisions and more chapters.

oof I totally know how you feel anon.
It's even worse when you have a hairstyle that's asymmetrical and you want to show it from both sides.
I've seen some artists just flip the hair depending on the angle to always show the good side but I feel like an idiot whenever I do that.
I hate creating inconsistencies, especially with something as small as hairstyles.
I haven't shied away from drawing my characters at certain angles but sometimes the hairstyle looks natural and other times it looks like dogshit.

But recently I've started constructing my hairstyles from the ground up like you would with a body instead of slapping shapes onto them until it looks good.
I've found that it's much easier to draw hairstyles at multiple angles that way.
Still not completely satisified but I'm getting there.

posts.name: Anonymous

Writing is just like drawing. Your first work will be complete garbage.
For some of the anons in this thread it might be their very first attempt at creating a comic.
Even if you know what makes a great comic great, actually putting in the time and making these ideas a reality is a different beast and incredibly humbling.
Playing it safe and creating something somewhat generic is way better for learning story writing, character writing, dialogue, pacing, paneling and so on instead of trying to make your magnum-opus on your first try.
They're doing their steps towards becoming better artists and writers by just creating something even if it's garbage and learning from it (hopefully).
You don't believe that all the successful comic-artists hit gold with their very first comic(s), do you?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6457614
>asymmetrical and you want to show it from both sides.
Yup that's one of my problems alright, and I also feel like an idiot when I do the magic side flip. That pic says it all.
My particular design isn't completely unrealistic so it is by all means possible to convincingly draw it from all angles, but it's not only time consuming but just a touch beyond my skill set. I'm really studying the shape of skulls and the way locks of hair grow out of them, but then I also have to convert that to stylized shapes that suit my chosen style. Figure out what liberties I should take with shape placement at awkward angles so it doesn't look goofy. And then I'll have to be consistent with it every goddamn time. Bodies and clothing inconsistencies can be forgiven but when a characters head looks off, everyone can immediately tell something is off. I'm always amazed how mangaka keep their art so crisp for 10+ years at a time.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6466457
I can relate to wanting to leave 4chan, although when I'm bored at work and none of my friends are online, I tend to come here anyway...
But really, most people I know think themselves socially inept, just be forgiving of yourself when you're being embarrassing, it happens to all of us.
At least the online folks don't know your face.
You could just randomly check out some discord art servers and you don't actually need an account if you're just taking a look for most of them:
https://discordservers.com/browse/art
https://discord.com/servers?query=Art
When you want to get involved with people, you'll have to take initiative and try to find the people who're open enough to make space for you though.
There are "art communities" on all social media, but I think especially small discord servers make things easier.
There're also art subreddits, deviantArt groups, art aminos, mastodon art groups, also twitter and instagram clusters of artists who make art challenges and draw each others OCs... You can find art people in most image sharing communities if you look hard enough.
There're also online art collaboration tools you could check out, like DrawPile and alternatives https://alternativeto.net/software/drawpile/?p=2
I've joined random art rooms in different programs and met people that way, although it's been the easiest to bond over fandom hype stuff; I got new discord contacts who in turn invited me to new art servers to explore.
I hope it'll be as fun for you as it was for me; good luck, anon!

>>6459528
The tapered strokes in the clothing creases make me think he's using pressure for size
There's a hotkey to enable/disable it in photoshop but even without that you can keep the line weight consistent if your pressure control is good enough.
Also, I don't think it's uncommon to go back and fine tune line weight throughout after the initial drawing, using restating/vector tools/etc. IIRC DAB tells you to do something like this for thickening the outer boundaries. What you see might be multiple passes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>>6459528
nice, play with the brush settings try reducing the flow of the ink-3 gpen to 34%. on preassure control I think a S curve is the best in responsiveness vs dynamic range ( ink-3 gpen already has a nice s curve on size pressure). another thing to consider is hardware e.g. wacom pro pen 2 is way more dynamic range than say wacom 4k pen this allows to control better the line weight (this is the main reason people say pro nibs are eaten away faster). and the most important experience are you sure there are no double passes or erasing on the og?

ok then we can rule hardware sensitivity out (remember its not really important it only matters on how you set up your tools).
Then I suggest to play around with technics, leave that alone and practice a little of contour lines, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=97-LDiSaam4 after some practice come back to the gyaru and redo her.
A tip for overlapping lines, create a tmp layer now use big (huge) gesture for the new line, erase until both lines seamless join together (no bumps) then merge down. and the bigger the canvas the better.

>>6463410
Aim for 3-4 heads tall
Head should be roughly size of the rib cage, thigh, calf, etc etc. There is general proportional similarity when it comes to body parts. You can sell shortness by enlarging the head, just made sure the facial features arent enlarged TOO enlarged or itll look chibi and very young. accentuate hips and boobs accordingly. Squish proportions as well. You can also sell shortness by incorporating size difference, like a normal human size male or a human sized door or something like that

Best bet is find ref you like and redline trace the proportions so its easier to digest, and copy them for your work

glad it helped you
>I do wish however the pen would not use grey when the line is very thin as it hampers and forces contour lining
play with the settings, now you have a little grasp of what opacity, flow, etc does you can go read the documentation of krita for brush dont expend too much time on it, just enough to have fun around. try basic-5 brushe it should have enough flow for what you want.

another thing you can do while having all your lineart in a separate group, create a new layer on top, alpha lock it and paint over the parts you would like darker.

look closer at your drapery, look that their is more variation in the line weight in the og, also there are more broken lines, it gives a more loose feeling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464996
>do you mean grouping all my line arts, having an extra layer on top of the group
yes
-lineart group
--eraser (eraser blending mode)
--darkener (alpha lock x)
--line3
--line2
--line1

then use the darkener layer to change color of the lines, also for experimenting you can also create a layer on top called eraser and now you can erase non destructively to test any crazy idea you have.

for this ideas to work, they have to belong to the same group

>>6436845
This isn't a comment I got but these 2 characters I've been fleshing out for a comic for years, ended up getting "copied" by 2 big name cartoon shows like 4 years after I imagined them myself. It pissed me off at first, but I didn't let it get to me. I resolved instead to adjust my characters and their narrative world in a way that mogs those cartoons(in my opinion,) and makes my characters even more distinctly my own. I'll never get famous from it and retards might still try to compare my characters (which came first) to the characters from the cartoons, or even some unpredictable media I've never heard of. But I'll never doubt myself about it and that's what matters. My creations have a life of their own, it's my job to convince people to see them as distinct, and hell it might even be fun to lean into some of the comparisons for laughs. If you aren't fighting tooth and nail to carve out your own identity through your creations you're just too weak.

>>6439229
lol i'm a person who says this sometimes (paired with other advice). i don't say "looks like shit" because it's just not a useful citicism
it doesn't tell the other person what they did wrong or how to improve on the picture or which skill they should focus on
furthermore, it's not like putting a lot of effort into a shitty image has never happened to me - i assume the other person already knows their work looks "bad somehow" but doesn't know how to fix it, and that in that state it's pretty easy to fall into the trap of thinking all the time you put into something was a total waste and a sign that you have hit a "wall" and will never improve.
so, in combination with other suggested practical solutions, it's just a reminder that time invested into practice isn't useless, at a time when it is easy to think that way, and have that mentality block your growth.

Artists to want their work to be recognized as unique and original, it can be frustrating to feel like your art is being compared or overshadowed by someone else's work. This is especially true if the other artist is very well-known, as opposed to an obscure artist(in which case you'd be happy to find some else knows that artist too?).

It's also possible that the artist feels like their art is being judged based on the similarities, rather than on its own merit.

>>6428967
Tried out SG Pen and the Ink Brush, wasn't close to it. So I made this custom brush from a hodge podge of a bunch of brush materials I cannibalized.

I'm not particularly skilled at art, and especially at anime so sorry for the bad drawing. This was to see if I could get close to the original. It was drawn in 1600x2000 then cropped down mainly with the brush size between 12, 16, 20, 24, and 32 depending on what the line thickness is. It's not a good brush for a single line drawing. Instead, you'll have to draw over your lines multiple times to get it to be thick. Keep it light and fast for the "skippy" thin lines. I highly suggest holding your pen either the way Nagabe holds his pen for solid lines and a looser grip for the skippy ones.

https://files.catbox.moe/1ndnwq.sut

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Drawing from life is a common trap that most beginners fall for, and do without understanding its significance, because someone that was better at drawing than them told them that they needed to draw from life. Pic related is an example of such an attempt and these artists tend to wonder why it is these beginners draw so terribly as if they are trolling or not even trying but just as the beginner does not understand the significance of drawing from life, so does the seasoned artist not understand how a beginner typically sees the world.

One way to immediately realize if you're looking at something wrong, especially when it comes to drawing from life, is to trace over the drawing directly but pretending as if you are simply copying it. This means that you approach the drawing not by outlining the contours but by drawing it the way you would typically draw it if you were to copy it. One thing you will immediately notice is that despite you copying directly onto the image itself, therefore negating any issues with proportions, your drawing still looks like shit. Why the hell is that??? You'd think that if a beginner traced over a drawing, it would not look so bad but that is not the case.

When a beginner attempts to draw from life, they are essentially trying to copy that trace that they drew out. In doing so, they end up copying an already shitty trace or representation of an image which will obviously lead to an even shittier copy of that image. Basically, if you can't make something look good tracing directly over it--acting as if you are copying it as you do trace it (using the image merely as a means to get accurate proportions), how the fuck do you expect to be able to copy it directly? You cannot.

This is why tracing must be used in order learn how to make something look good. Once you've attained the ability to trace over life and make it look good, THEN you can attempt to copy it.

Or, you can just copy other artists and skip this step entirely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Of course, this mainly applies to drawing from life as the lines are not as immediately explicit as, say, lineart from another artist--which is why I said in the end that you can copy other artists and skip this step entirely.

This is also why it's seemingly easier to copy anime than it is to copy from life. It is not necessarily the fact that drawing from life is more difficult thought that does play a role, but rather the lines are more explicit in anime and you know where the line stops and where the line ends.

This is why it is imperative that you copy from other artists first to see how they draw something rather than guessing how you should draw something like an eye or a nose. Many different artists have many different ways to approach drawing the facial features and you will see that they typically do not draw what they see but rather use life as a template on which to place their style onto.

This is why I believe telling beginners to draw from life is a trap if you do not first warn them of these facts. The beginner will become frustrated that what they draw looks like shit when what they are drawing is a bad representation of a tracing that they are thinking of.


Or maybe that is the point. Maybe the whole point is to purposely disparage aspiring artists so that they quit because they think the act of drawing is far too abstract or abstruse to understand. I don't know what /ic/'s aim is here to be completely honest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The thing most artists don't understand is that beginners have shitty line control. They quite literally do not know how to control their pens/pencils properly. That's why they fail at tracing and drawing from life. Line control is key but it's so fundamental as to be almost invisible to someone who does it naturally.

>>6466710
I don’t think shaky or bad lines leads to a bad drawing, it’s much more complex than that. And I should know because I was a savant at drawing straight lines and my boxes are pretty damned good yet I was fucking garbage at drawing. I didn’t get better at drawing, I just got better at making straight lines.

While line work improves an artists work, it doesn’t make them go from /beg/ to /int/
They’ll still be /beg/ but it’ll be more obvious because their lines are so wrong and confident at the same time.

The biggest hurdle is not being able to stylize correctly and trying to draw exactly what they are looking at which always leads to bad results. Artists never copy what they are looking at—unless they’re doing hyperrealism—they always stylize it. The amount of stylization depends on how much closer to life they want to make it but there is no doubt there is a bit of stylization going on in every single drawing otherwise they’d look off and clearly traced.

The best thing to do would be to copy other artists and analyze how they draw certain things. Once you have an idea on how they do it, you apply that to real life and you’ll see the results from before and after are drastically different.

posts.com:
>>6467567
I don't know if you just don't understand what "trace" means or if you don't understand what "drawing from life" means, but those two are pretty much mutually exclusive.
Drawing from life means drawing things that are literally in the 3D space in front of you. The opposite of drawing from existing 2D images like photos or the art of other people.
Tracing means literally dragging your pencil, or other drawing apparatus, over the lines in an existing 2D picture. You can do this by placing your empty paper on top of another paper containing the original and tracing whatever you see through the paper. Or do the same by abusing layers in drawing software.
There's no real way of doing this from life. You could try having a glass in between you and your subject and tracing on it but this requires you to keep your head 100% motionless which is pretty hard in itself.

This is one of the very reasons why life drawing is recommended. It straight up eliminates one of the cheapest and most common methods of cheating. It forces you to observe and understand instead of just mechanically copying.

You and OP are right but the wording bothers me a bit. Symbol drawing is useless language in any context but a person trying to copy a subject exactly. A beginner's exercise.
It's got nothing to do with whether something lacks form, has bad perspective, or is clearly a fake/generic rendition of something they've never drawn before, but people use it as a catch-all buzzword for those cases anyway. Nothing in an artist's work other than studies will actually consist of "what they see instead of what they interpret", unless the person only transfers photographs to a new surface using a grid. Since all artists stylize the subject it's counterproductive to use it outside of context.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

>>6458068
>dials
1 for zooming in/out, that when pressed, will return to 100% zoom
1 for rotating canvas, that when pressed, will flip the canvas
1 for brush size, that when pressed, will toggle between your selected tool and eraser

>buttons
1 for undo
1 for redo
1 for selection tool
1 for free transform
1 for copy
1 for paste
1 for new layer
1 for eye dropper
1 for sketch brush
1 for blend tool

I'm sure there are tools I'm not thinking of that I'd like mapped as well, but a 12-15 key pad with 3 dials would be my ideal.

2 of those are mapped to my pen though, so 12 keys would be adequate I think.

>>6445010
Speaking as an owner of one, if you want a screenless tablet that's as good as the intuos pro L, then you aren't going to find anything better than the intuos pro L. The chinese screenless tablets are something like 90% as good for 20-30% of the price, but if you really care about that last 10% then there is no replacement. The replaceable surfaces are really nice too, I use a rough texture sheet and it's glorious to draw on, though it eats nibs like crazy.

For what it's worth I also have a kamvas 22 plus that I got for roughly the same price as the intuos and I end up using that a bit more often. Screened tablets beat the pants off of screenless ones every day of the week tbdesu, you can get used to the hand-eye disconnect, but drawing on a screen is just a bit more effortless in my opinion.

friendly dokiwear shill here (I wish, the company sucks dick at marketing)
I ordered a v3 just to check it out and it came in the mail today. Initial impressions, I don't really like it. If you have carpal tunnel or are at significant risk of it it's probably good, but I don't draw all day every day so doubt I'm at much risk. The wrist opening is fucking small, so getting the glove on/off is a bit of a pain. I'm used to taking my glove off multiple times a day because it's a bit weird to type with it, and this wouldn't let me do that.
The velcro on the wrist strap is also pointlessly strong, and I feel like the loop side will get fuzzy/wear out pretty fast.
The small wrist opening should stretch a bit over time, but ultimately I'm probably just going to stick to my v2 (of which I ordered 2 more in case this company goes belly up from their shit ass lack of marketing skills)

Oh also I guess I ordered the last medium v3 anyway, so unless you're a supreme manlet (xs), fucking giant (xl), or subhuman (lefty) they don't have any in stock anyway.

>>6464068
Read how stable diffusion actually works. It basically trains the algorithm to denoise a generated noisy image over a number of iterations to produce an image (along with whatever NLP algorithm is used to interpret the initial prompt). Also it's unsupervised learning, meaning there is no real validation afterwards, it just returns after running.

What it means is that if the training images already have some proc generated watermark all over it, generated in a way that it couldn't easily be removed by existing watermark removal tools, than any generated images of that artist's artstyle (ie. generate xyz in the style of so and so) would try to include those watermarks as well and it would make it really obvious that it was AI generated because they'd likely be fucked up looking in ways a human could easily determine (ie. similar to how SD has no concept of how many fingers a hand has and constantly generates fucked up looking ones)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464025
Retrained how?
Let me put it this way
1. Artist A posts a lot of public art, but all there art includes some watermark repeated, but altered in some semi random way based on a seed/key that only they have

2. This art is scraped and used as a training dataset for an art generation AI

3. Someone only enters the prompt "I want this image in artist A's style" and the AI creates an image

Now, because all of the artists images included that watermarking, the AI will naturally try to include something similar to it, but without knowing that initial seed/key the original artist will have an easy way of proving that this is a generated version, not authentic.

And even if someone altered the prompt to not include the watermark, and it manages to generates something that looks remotely convincing (although it's unclear if it could or how well it would look) given that all of the publicly available images include them, that's also a giveaway

Make sense

>>6445520
Nice, colors look good. One thing I'll say though is that because the shapes aren't totally accurate, some of the magic of the light source is lost. E.G.: the match flame in the ref is sitting in his cupped hand, and the light coming through the fingers emphasizes this. Your flame is about the same distance from the cigarette, but the hand is further away, so it doesn't quite sell the illusion of the skin glowing in the same way - it looks sort of like there's a second, invisible flame further towards his palm. This is hugely nitpicking though, thanks for posting.

Shit happens and all you can do is move forward. I spent my entire teens + early adulthood symbol drawing with little to no actual guidance because I didn't know how/where to learn properly. But I'm doing studies *now* and feel better than ever whenever I see my small improvements.

That said fuck social media. Just post your work and move on (and you don't even really have to post your work anyways. Unless you're trying to make a career out of it your art should just be for you). In a few years from now you'll have an archive of all your progress and it won't feel so meaningless.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

Recommended watching:

>>6466732
I don't think you really understand what the term "master study" means judging by the crap you've been spamming anon.

A "master study" implies you're studying from an artist you consider well-rounded and of a higher, established skill level. You do so in order to break down and understand the process behind the picture, akin to reverse-engineering it. It has nothing to do with them being born centuries ago or having their works on a museum's wall. Even studying someone else's study can be considered a master study.
The medium and style said artist is using only matters to you. If you believe Miyazaki's drawings possess something you want to extract and instill into your own art, then he is a master to you and studying his work counts as a master study. Same goes for some famous Twitter artist you look up to.

Forcing an anti-Japanese culture narrative or pretending to objectify what should be valued as masterful or not in the end just tells more about you people's petty complexes more than anything else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Getting good at illustration first before comic-making
posts.com: As a /beg/-/int/ who's art is still kind of shit by most standards and is just getting deep into fundies now, I am looking specifically to get good at dynamic poses and foreshortening, as well as being able to draw decent figures in perspective alongside pen & ink detail and a decent visual library for character design and vehicles. I am doing all of this specifically to make comics and personal projects, but I specifically want to know is at least spending 1/2 years on making single illustrations first just to get my art skills at a competent level worth it before getting into comics making fully? I developing an artstyle that lives by a solid understanding of some fundamentals like form, detailing and dynamicism, and if my comics visually fail at depicting those (which I still do even in my own art btw), they would kind of fall apart. Thoughts?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: You'll never feel "good enough" to make your masterpiece but you also won't BE good enough for quite a while. If you want to get better at making comics, make some comics. If they're bad you can just re-do them later. You know what areas you want to focus on, so there's nothing wrong with getting comfortable with the medium WHILE you work on those fundies.

posts.com:

Its like a 2 bird one stone thing where making comics forces you to draw a lot in volume which is what you need most to improve and become efficient

But again the keys is volume volume

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6467831
I know, but I am planning to do both comics and illustrations generally speaking when it comes to plans. Not to mention that my standards for visuals and concepts are much higher than almost everything posted on /mmg/ as well (Seriously, do people who only have been drawing for 6 months on average post their work here?). At least 1 year of grinding fundies and doing master studies might be enough for getting decent at figures, detailing and character design for the purposes of the story I want to tell rather than just working on some crappy one-shot and figuring out asome ugly art style for it and develop bad habits rather than improving (basically what Isayama did, which explains taking 10 years for going from total shit to barely mediocre). Also look at webcomics that tend to get a following without being webtoon goyslop. Ramia is literally created by a pro figure designer, and I doubt something like pic related would've been getting recognition if it wasn't drawn well.

TL;DR Some of us do care about visual quality as much as storytelling, and there's nothing wrong with it or waiting a bit more before attempting something if you aren't comfortable.

even if you aren't ready to start taking on a full on comic you should try to gear your practice towards sequential imagemaking if that is your goal. doing a page is a pretty different feeling than working on a single illustration.

posts.com:
>>6460328
To understand the meaning of "Just Draw" one must first understand that the true definition of talent is the ability to learn how to do something well with little to no instruction.

Now that we have that definition out of the way, we can begin with why the "just draw" phenomenon exists and why some people are able to actually benefit from the "just draw" when others seem to find it to be a trap.

Once we understand the definition of talent, we can now see why the "just draw" phrase is thrown around as if it was the most enlightened advice ever given. It is not because it actually works for everyone but rather that it works for anyone who has an innate ability to draw--innate not meaning "born with" but rather a proclivity towards drawing that creates a natural ability to learn things.

In order for "just draw" to actually work, one must have talent in drawing. This talent will allow you to be able to draw for hours and learn from your work and mistakes without any instruction whatsoever--though instruction could never hurt. If one does not have talent in drawing, they must seek out help in order to improve or else they will stagnate as pointed out by this anon: >>6463757

Basically, if you don't have talent, learning to draw will much harder and even if you do end up attaining a certain level of skill, your art will never be as good as most of the worst works from artists that do have talent which is why you have to find a reason to actually pursue art. You have to have a purpose as to why you are pursuing it rather than just the blind ambition of being able to draw le cute animu grill.

The real question we need to ask here is that if you do not possess such talent, would you still continue to draw? That is the real question you need to ask yourself here. That will allow you to determine whether or not to continue or if you should just quit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The path to getting gud is not a straight one. You need to keep moving to see where your strengths and weak points are, while also developing the habit and discipline every good professional needs to have

>>6463839
I guess a "talented" and skilled chef can taste a dish, determine if it tastes good or bad on a very refined level, and based on prior experimentation and a knowledge of how various spices taste, be able to determine how the dish could be salvaged, or if unsalvageable, how to make it better next time. This is the talented "just draw" artist.
A skilled but generally untalented chef can eventually do the above, but mostly due to having having been told what's good and what's bad, and having had their palette refined by way of a more skilled/talented chef telling them why exactly their dish tastes bad and how to improve it. Their innate sense is above average, but they still struggle to figure out how to improve their dishes without repeated explicit instruction. Eventually they put two and two together and start making their own judgments here and there. This is the fundies-grinder artist.
A basic cook can follow a recipe and get an OK result sometimes, but they have no desire to stray from the recipe and even then will sometimes fuck things up in hilariously bad fashion. They can kinda tell if something came out right, but are absolutely clueless if something goes wrong and lack the motivation to search for solutions. This would be a tracefag.

posts.com:
>>6465082
>What kind of benefits are you looking for?
>In this case, what do You want out of art?
I honestly don't know. I just get ideas that I think are worth realizing (but require very different skill sets to execute). I get super hyped for the final product, I finish it, and then reality sets in.
I'm asking /fag/ for advice because /fag/ at least seems to enjoy what they do.

I don't know if I do what I do out of boredom, delusions of grandeur or what. When I finish something, I get thoughts like "oh, well that was a waste of time and nobody cares about it, I should have spent this time doing something else". But then I get the next idea, and the cycle starts again.

I feel like I'm stuck in a catch-22 where I'll be disappointed in myself if I do nothing, but I'll always be disappointed by what I make.

It could be general negative thoughts from not having close friends or social status, but that's not easily fixed. It's difficult for me to build a circle around my hobbies because I jump ship too often to really "get good" at things (and being a /pol/cel doesn't help).

If I was smart, I would channel this energy into making some kind of soulless moneymaking machine, but alas. I can't learn to be content with vidya, weed and anime porn like normal people.

I think the TL;DR is that I keep chasing the dragon trying to make the next big thing, but I get easily discouraged and don't stick with things or chase trends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465582
It sounds like you're surrounding yourself with negative situations that'll never happen. Instead, why even worry about what ifs and just concern yourself about those issues Once you get to them (if they even ever come up). Overall, you're just over thinking and allowing your mind to wonder about possible negative outcomes that'll just never happen.
>I feel like I'm stuck in a catch-22 where I'll be disappointed in myself if I do nothing, but I'll always be disappointed by what I make.
I used to have this type of emotion. But in my case, I'd complete a drawing, be happy with it, and convince myself that I can never make anything as good ever again, and take me hours (sometimes days) to get the courage to draw up something again. I repeat this cycle upon each drawing, but now when I hear that voice I let it hang out with me. Instead of feeling doom, I'm just like "lmao you might be right" and just start on the next drawing soon after.
Overall, these emotions are gonna be hard to defeat. But instead of removing them, try to be friends with them. And you'll see why said emotions are making you think the way you are. Otherwise, you really have nothing to lose.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6467852
ink pens are a meme, you can achieve the same results with pencils if you have the discipline to not erase what you put down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6467764
Whatever pen you are most comfortable with. I recommend a micron PN it draws fast and makes solid line, but is more robust than a micron fine liner.

>>6467889
You can get a pencil-like effect with ballpoint, but I think that defeats the purpose. Because the lineweight and darkness is more fixed, it makes your line economy more important. And like this anon points out >>6467886 you are more thoughtful with construction.

I actually draw in pencil now and don’t erase because it moves faster and I like how it feels on toothy paper. Pens can still skip and the nibs wear down super fast.

>>6467852
Do timed figure drawing sessions in pen and you will learn how to build up the figure with minimal lines.

I think i hit limit growth. I cant grow past around 2.2k followers (on twitter)

I post frequently and get around 600 likes on a good day but followers are going up very slowly.

Should i draw for a different audience? More original content? Or should i just try to improve my skills?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6451767
I dont remember right now in previous versions, but you can press 'P' as a hotkey for the color picker

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460515
It's good that you took the time to finish it. Think of the first parts of the drawing step as being more important to the final work than anything else. Check all of your proportions to your reference, and when you aren't sure about something then you'll know what gaps in your knowledge you have to fill in. Be very careful not to simply copy what you see without thinking about it, as you'll grow very fast by being mindful of what you're doing. Keep finishing your painting like you've done here, and enjoy it. Keep sharing it with us.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460526
With the grid. I just draw the important outlines. the pencil lines would be as detailed as this pic from google. Important contours such as the clavicle would also be marked with a line.
I take advantage of the very fast drying time of acrylic paint, I can just slather on colours without regard if it actually matches the reference image and I'll fix it on subsequent layers. This is why I prefer it to oil.

I'd disagree. I think it can matter a lot.

They would need to somehow find a lot of the different socials I'm posting with (which have different usernames), with a lot of my work being posted to obscure enough places like 4chan (which is notoriously bad at making things easy to find through archives). I don't plan on posting a lot to mainstream social media, so it shouldn't be easy to google for.

Additionally it looks like; the more isolated and simple a concept, the easier it is to train against. For example an individual character surrounded by a blank background. So if I have a particular IP or story I want to be protective of, I'd focus on posting work that's difficult to train against like that. So mostly complex finished pieces, that have a lot of different things going on, lots of perspective etc. I genuinely think this would be a meaningful deterrent. They could maybe copy some of the style with these pieces, but not so easily the content.

Like the reason why the Sam Does Arts models are so effective, are because he'd draw the same thing over and over again in a similar way, with relatively simple backgrounds etc. Then he'd have a massive body of work easily accessible through one or two mainstream sites.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I see people seethe about AI, I wonder if this is how tradcucks reacted to the rise of digital art. Including the whole "muh soul" stuff.
AI is a tool. It's not supposed to be self-sufficient, just like a stabilizer in your drawing software of choice is not supposed to automatically solve all your lineart issues.
First of all, AI is the (potentially) ultimate referencing tool. For example, you wanna draw Makise Kurisu in Soejima's style, but you have no clue where to start. So just input a simple prompt, and bam, you have something like this. That is certainly good enough. The clothes are all wrong, but you're not an artist for nothing, you can fix that yourself. So copy it, add your own flavor, or try something else entirely, do whatever you want.
Second, AI is really good at inpainting. If you need a quick fix, or you don't like how something looks - consult the AI and see what it gives you, it takes seconds and maybe you'll find something inspiring.
Third, AI is really good at backgrounds. It paints huge complicated scenes of any variety in seconds. I don't even have to explain how that can be useful to someone who only draws anime girls and doesn't care about landscapes, but still needs landscapes in their art.

Work smarter, not harder. AI is a godsend for a hobbyist digicuck who simply wants to have fun drawing sexy girls, which is at least 80% of /ic/s population. Obviously, if you wanna take your art one step further and become a professional, AI won't help you much. But most of us are not doing this shit for a living, we just wanna draw cute anime girls in our free time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6461201
The things i find interesting in a piece are often the weird and esoteric details that make up the whole and are often the parts i like the most in art, especially my own, but these things only end up there because of the artist being a hyperfocused autist about such things. It's each of those individual weird esoteric decisions i make when drawing that gives me the most dopamine and why i'm personally not threatened in ai in my own use because clicking generate feels about the same as seeing someone else's art.

But the issue overall i think is about how much it closes the gap between artist and non-artist. It shrinks the skill distance by like orders of magnitude, more so then i feel anything previously ever has with maybe the exception of the invention of the camera. But even then art was still capable of going in other wildly different directions then just life renders, that they could separate themselves from that space the camera now crowded, and survive as a medium as they began to really exploit the uniqueness of their craft. But its unclear if we can do that now. I'm not sure what will separate a future more-nuanced user of a more advanced ai and that of the artist other then those weird, esoteric, little details that artists obsess over. But no one will give a shit about those, it's consumer grade tech, now operable by significantly less skilled and therefore cheaper technicians, that creates great consumer grade art. Stuff the consumers will love. Slowly the beauty of the details in the craft become just another entry to the "critically endangered crafts" list. Because what will artists have left to move into that ai can't or won't soon do other then some of those tiny "insignificant" details? If we even have those.

>the current apprehensions from people as of now has more to do with a strong aversion to the "idea" of looking at ai art not the art itself
That's because most people intuitively understand that something being ai generated sucks all the meaning out of it, no matter if it looks "pretty" on the surface. This is why the average normie might praise an artwork but as soon as you tell them it's ai generated, they just go "oh" and lose interest immediatly. There is actually a bit of a shitstorm on twitter right now because some mental health advisor made an experiment where some people got ai generated "support" for their problems that they appreciated at first, yet as soon as they learned it was ai generated, they felt betrayed:
>https://twitter.com/RobertRMorris/status/1611450197707464706

Ai "art" suffers from the same issues. People see art as a form of communication, something that lets them understand each other's intentions. A machine can do none of that, it can only pretend. And as long as we don't have truly sentient machines (which is a whole different can of worms), this problem will remain. The only ones who MAY be interested in using ai art are soulless coorporations but those still have to worry about the whole copyright and public outrage hell that comes with using it for their products.

A hammer doesnt build a fucking house for you, it provides a hard surface and a lever to make the job of driving nails into wood easier.

A brush doesnt paint a painting for you when you ask it to, it keeps your hands clean while it pushes paint around and aids the accuracy of that paint getting to where you want it.

A wacom tablet and drawing software doesnt draw a digital picture for you, the tablet serves to record human input while the software interpolates the input that you provide as digital "medium" that shows up on the monitor allowing you to slowly build up a digital image with said medium, replacing your art supplies and allowing you to draw infinitely and reproduce/edit/manipulate your work to your hearts content.

Ai art generators take a simple written word prompt and then completely convert it into a finshed piece of work which is based/derivative of pre existing work that artists have done and posted online. It allows you to literally "generate" at the touch of a button, an image that you had no control or command over other than the content. You didn't compose it, you didnt light it, you didnt render it, you didnt draw its structure or underlying forms. It reduces you to an infant spinning a kaleidoscope around, and like a particularly stupid infant might, you think that somehow makes you the, "artist", in the situation.

Tools dont literally do the entire job for you, theres a difference between a tool and an automaton, and we have now entered the age of art automatons, (a machine that performs a function according to a predetermined set of coded instructions, especially one capable of a range of programmed responses to different circumstances).

>>6461201
>I wonder if this is how tradcucks reacted to the rise of digital art.
oldfag here. I remember it being so gradual that few made a big deal about it. Digital was mainly for graphic design & video games before it evolved to a point where it could be a viable alternative to traditional media. The only pushback I vaguely remember were articles discussing how digital was a poor substitute for the tactile quality of traditional, and some drawing/painting teachers gently mocking the graphic design students for using computer programs (not getting their hands dirty).
It's only in retrospect I'm more critical of the widespread adoption of digital (and I was an early adopter). It reinforced an aesthetic that basically paved the way for AI, an over-rendered, sterile aesthetic that increasingly used 3D and photo bashing, leaving less evidence of the human hand.
For the record I do agree the PROCESS differs between digital & AI, but I predict aesthetically the two will be linked together. I hope for a trad backlash, even if it's just a niche counterculture.

Burne hogarth, Loomis, Michael Hampton and Vilppu are the general go tos method on /IC but there's dozens more you can prob find.

>>6461718

You are misinformed. When we say "loomis" on this board it's just a shorthand way of directing someone to the fundamentals without having to type out a wall of text for every stupid question. Newfags don't understand this. The Loomis books are a great coffee mat on your desk and can be flipped through to understand what something the fundies are.

For example, if Emilie receives her fist "How to Draw Manga Book" and she's copying the images in the book she is making more progress than half of the /beg/ thread. Then she decides she wants to take it a step further past front-view head drawings but doesn't know anything about form. Flipping through loomis opens her eyes to what form is, because the gimmick book left out this information. She understands, puts the loomis book away, and continues to draw what she wants, incorporating the wisdom loomis said but not literally drawing old man blooks.

Of course, Loomis is taken as a meme. The point here is (and it was brought up before ITT) you're supposed to draw what you want. If DABman says to jump and you say "from where" and he says "from the tallest building in NYC" you're not supposed to do it. Or else you'll always be dependent on someone else giving you assignments.

As for the course itself, I can't tell you. I do agree with others that the 250 number seems arbitrary, but to a beginner, it appears to be more of a concrete goal than the 'just keep drawing' advice. It's probably which why a lot of beginners keep falling for it.

The reality is that it can take you years to get to a point you are happy with and even then it might take you even longer or you may never get to point where you're happy with your work. The most important thing is to keep practicing and learning. Even those work you may not completely like might have something valuable for you to learn.

Hampton or Vilppu for introductory gesture/figure drawing, whichever clicks the most for you or hell do both. Then the Bridgman grind. IMO

Fellow Artist of all level welcome :)
Mutual motivation and Drawing together!

[[[ RULES ]]]

Realistically Keep drawing time between 30 minutes ~1 hour.

Subject Humanoid, SFW, tasteful lewd ok but nothing Explicit.

Keep the Exchanges on 1:1 Artist pairing, so FIRST Reply bases.
Try Starting a New request if an exchange is already active.
Remember to post Sample and be willing to return the favour.

Be Respectful, have Fun and share Love <3

posts.com:
>>6450621
Ok, its different.
I used to draw 2D years ago, I always loved art. I was also working with 3D stuff. But a couple of years ago I really wanted to try sculpting my own characters and trying that route.

3D as other person said adds that extra dimension and, unless you are not going to rotate a single degree your camera, everything can go wrong with just small movement. Do you know how in 2D drawing you are always mirroring the image just in case theres something wrong you didnt see because your mind got used to it?
Well, in 3D you keep rotating the model, zooming in, seeing how that face looks in that angle, from behind, profile, activating the perspective, adjusting the fov...

And thats only the sculpting thing. Then theres the UV, rig, weight painting, texturing (painting), knowledge of many programs (well I dont use Blender), retopo, baking textures, lighting, camera setup, animating and other extra things in Unreal like adding particles, C++ programming, cloth physics, environmental design, props, etc etc.
