>>6450941
well lets see here.

a good sculpting engine will handle several million polies without issue, so there is no reason to retop unless you want to animate or make a low poly version for a game

modeling is not hard, but it can be a bit paint by numbers and not fun, especially when its small shit for a background. (protip, if the shit is small enough to never be a focal point, draw it in as a 2d plane and be done with it, think plants and shit going up a building in the background, its never going to be close up enough to be seen so why do it right?)

texturing isn't hard, there are litteral banks of free texture data, if you are to retarded to know how to use them then 3d is beyond you

you don't need to rig or weight paint unless you animate, rigging is so retardedly simple I was able to do it as a kid in the 90's much less re doing it a few years ago because I wanted to try something.

weight painting is again, not hard.

lighting is literally done for you unless you are too retarded to understand the fundamentals of lighting a shot (protip, room lighting, positional lighting and bounce lighting are needed in every room unless you are going for a specific look. look into irl lighting to help you)

you only animate if you want to animate, and at this point 3d, and every step to get to animateing is easier and faster than doing the animation traditionally even when you think the 3d artist is a 100% beginner, and the 2d animator is a veteran who knows what they are doing the 3d will churn something out faster.

If you're gona make a product with a vision in mind and with a level of mastery then yes it is hard. You would have to have a thorough understanding of anatomy to be able to sculpt a believable human character. Then when it comes down to texturing you'll have to work with skin tones, bumps and differences in skin etc.. the list goes on almost ad-infinitum. If you just want to create a basic human and you don't care about these subtle yet important details you'll end up with a generic monstrosity of a model like the vast majority of finished models out there.
It's not too hard to go through the process if you're a braindead cow but if you actually set high standards for yourself it is.
Look at the character sculpts made for dishonored 2 and compare them with models you'll find on any assetstore...

It's not that the tools themselves are hard to master necessarily but rather that the people who use rarely are able to discern due to lack of fundamental understanding and knowledge..

go with a style that lends itself well to real time or near real time rendering, this way you side step the autistic need to get everything 100% perfect, pick your shots so you never empathise anything that is shoddy, you want easier times animating hands or movement, get a setup that will read your movements or rotoscope from camera, both are relatively cheap.

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

posts.com:
>>6465776
assistants tools usually take cpu cycles to keep calculating stuff even on idle, this may cause lag on bigger projects, also the farther the vanishing points the more resource it may use...

Using a image template (raster level) there is no thinking involve, so less prone in lagging another benefit is that as the template is just another layer I can apply all the functions available to layers (blending modes, stacking order, masking, etc.) I can't imagine making something like a comic strip in which every panel may have a different vanishing points from each other with assistants tools.
Ended up using this templates, https://www.davidrevoy.com/article814/perspective-grids-for-comics-in-krita
but I think I will make an 8k version.

Did I make myself understood?, I'm mentally drained kek

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6465902
I think you should trace real people and anime characters, and get a feel for the curves, anatomy and how they are normally shaped.
You have some idea on what to do, but you may over exxagerate some stuff to a point thing it may look wrong, tracing should help bring it back to normal levels.
The word tracing may sound icky, but it helped for me and made me see what i got wrong despite figure drawing and study constantly, tracing just made it click.

If it helps, make some notes; i made the hp bone too sharp, my toes have too much definition, my shoulders are not as slender. Do stuff like that and you'll get afeel for how it's meant to be.

Wacum:
>Extremely overpriced to the point of comedy. I assume they price their shit so high because they know giant studios (blizzard, disney, etc) won't blink an eye at dropping $200,000 to replace their displays with the "latest and greatest"

Huion:
>Same build quality and drawing feel as wacom (both use etched glass displays with very similar pens)
>Requires color calibration, but when calibrated, very slightly worse color gamut compared to wacom. Should get around 96% adobe rgb
Buy if you want the "premium" chink tablet. Get their plus or pro line. 24" qhd is about $700, 24" 4k is about $1300. 22 plus is around $400-500 and is a very comfy size.

XP-Pen:
>Build quality seems slightly less consistent than Huion or Wacom, but still very solid
>Colors are kinda weird and not possible to accurately calibrate (seriously, tried for over an hour to adjust the contrast and it was always too high)
>Pen felt the worst of the 3 brands I tried with too long of a nib and again wouldn't calibrate properly
>Matte screen protector instead of etched glass. Will wear out over time and need to be replaced, and feels worse than etched glass
>new same price as huion, but cheaper to buy used (saw several 24" pros for $350 6 months ago)
Buy if you want a solid drawing experience, if you're buying used and want to save money, or if you absolutely need a dial on the side of your monitor. Otherwise just get huion.

Everything else (Gaomon, Ugee, whatever):
Don't bother, get one of the big 3.

>>6462015
I'm >>6461374, Lucid dreaming can be indeed hard to achieve and mantain, especially for people like us who don't exprience them naturally and effortlessly.

The basis is always dream journaling. You need to teach your brain that dreams are important, doing so will make them more vivid and detailed.
Then you need to set up a practice, make yourself think about lucid dreams all day, do MILD, WILD, and WBTB.
Perform reality checks, reminding yourself that the focus of them is awareness not the action.

Unfortunately, not practicing for a long time brings you back to the beginning. However, you don't lose your experiences and what you learned.

I too have let my LD skills go rusty, which can't be helped because I cycle between many hobbies.
It does piss me off that WILD is once again nearly impossible to perform, even though I had gotten decent at slipping aware straight into dreams, but I know I can get back to that level if I practice seriously.

I never tried supplements, so I don't really know their effectiveness. But if you don't practice the proper techniques, no amount of supplement is gonna do much.

I should weave lucid dreaming along some other mindfulness practice, but it's gonna be hard if my clients keep stressing me with shitty webdev jobs.
Stress destroys dream awareness, or awareness in general.

>>6462232
It's either praying the RNG or getting serious enough that you start getting serious results.
Personally, it's worth doing the latter at least once in life, so you get a chance to actually do some proper dreamwork. I've learned many things about the mind and myself.

If you want an all around practice to follow, you could try following the practice from "The Tibetan Yogas Of Dream And Sleep" book.
And I mean really following the practice to the letter. Bonus points if you understand why it would work and which techniques they interwove in that practice.

One of my two of my most successful runs was by following that practice.
The other was achieved by the usual techniques. dream journaling, RC, ADA, MILD, WILD and WBTB.
The difference from those successes and the halfassed attempts I do at getting back into it is the level of commitment.

I wish I had further tricks to reveal, or some easy way to cheat, but so far I got nothing.
I don't do supplements and I never tried those fancy LD inducing devices.

What I do is try to keep my dream journal going, so it's easier to get back into it whenever I feel like it. I just wish I had an easier time, like those motherfuckers who dickwave spewing bullshit like "I want to stop lucid dreaming lol". They're not even aware how they're wasting that precious gift.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6463051
>how? what's the cheat code?
The cheat code is the following:
1. Draw something from ref.
2. Cover the ref and the drawing.
3. Draw it again from memory.
4. Uncover, compare drawings, note mistakes.
5. Repeat, Repeat with a different angle.

As your visual library and recall is strengthened, your ability to use them in creative ways improves. You can invent new things based on your understanding of a subject. Pick subjects you are very interested in.

The "language" of art is in things like subtle variation of line weight, color choices, perspective, lighting, composition, layering, hatching, shape design. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6462388
Blindly means without thinking. If someone does something cool, you draw it. No analysis, no thinking. If you mess something up, you fix it. you might spend 200 hours on the same image. By the end, you are simply able to do way more than when you began the image.

Photo studies are bad because they do not teach anything about artistic process. Many artists have a different workflow for photos than they do for personal work, or even master studies (copying other artwork). Photos should be referenced or analyzed. Copying them is often useless, unless the exact image is used for illustration purposes.

It can. Just not by people. The only teacher is nature. Go look at some nature (stuff) and draw it (stuff). That's how you learn to draw.

You can divide this up into steps, like,
1. Observe
2. Analyze
3. Make the observations and analysis part of your being.

and for that, we have three drawing methods

1. Contour drawing
2. Construction drawing
3. Gesture drawing

But ultimately, one learns to draw by drawing, and by comprehending nature, not by following advice, least of all mine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450840
>drawabox
No wonder drawing makes you feel like ass. I can't imagine doing that crap and I've been drawing for years. I don't know if it'll help but I'll lend you some of my advice. Pick your favorite artist you want to draw like and start copying their stuff. Not serious 1:1 studies, just make some shitty doodles with whatever looks cool to you. In my case I just copied Akira panels because I always loved it. I must've copied half the series at some point. After a while I began to understand how Otomo drew figures. I didn't realize then that I was basically just doing figure studies, just not with irl people. Some time later I got confident enough to learn from other artists I admired and got better at copying, then I actually went over the fundies books that everyone pushes on prebegs. I felt like I learned in reverse but there is no wrong way to learning as long as you're making progress. Another piece of advice is to grow some skin and learn to take and LISTEN to advice from your superiors and apply it. Don't assume you know better when someone tells you this shading is inconsistent or this fold doesn't make sense etc.

Point is, while art is practice and hard work, it doesn't mean you can't have fun. Like with working out, you can make fun out of activities.

>>6450706
I admit I was mad at first about AI because I felt like it was taking away my opportunity to make it as an artist, but the more I think about it:
>I never wanted to do commission work anyway, since drawing other people’s OCs seemed really boring to me, I’d rather draw my own characters
>I never wanted to draw “flavor of the month” characters, ie whatever Nintendo girl is popular right now, I just want to draw characters I like
>I never wanted to pay attention to numbers on social and obsessing over what stuff gets the most engagement, stressing over likes/retweets takes the joy out of drawing
Etc. Of course, I’d still do a lot of that stuff, just because I wanted to “make it” and not because I actually wanted to draw it. And even with doing that, the truth is the chances of “making it” were always infinitesimally low, so I’ve realized AI never took away my chance, I never had a chance in the first place.
Of course, that doesn’t mean I’m going to quit drawing, since I still enjoy drawing. It just means I can focus now on doing what I want to do, and drawing what I want to draw, and if I can get some income off of that then that’s nice, but I’m not going to go into it with the illusion that I can actually make a career off of it.
In a way, I feel like this is a healthier mentality to approach art anyway.

>>6451882
Other anons have answered this question satisfactorily but I wish to illustrate an ideology that has allowed me to understand this phenomenon that you are upset about.

There are three types of people in any skill:
>The Performer
>The Entertainer
>The Teacher

All people who perform a skill will fall into these specific categories. Lets explain each one individually so that you can understand their significance and why it is we the encounter situations that you have described.

>The Performer
This is the person that wants to be "the best." These are people like Kim Jung Gi or the old masters who were really, really good at drawing.
The downside with trying to be a performer however, is that the bar is EXTREMELY high. No one really cares about you unless you perform like the top 1%. Otherwise, you are ignored.
Performers also tend to be the worst teachers and not very entertaining at all.

>The Entertainer
This is what you have encountered. Someone who isn't very good at drawing but makes up for it with their humor and entertaining personality.
They typically will not be very good teachers because they usually are not very good at drawing to begin with.
These will be the people that make the performers envious about their subscribers.
Unrelated to art, NeatMike, who isn't very good at Rocket League, is one of the most popular YouTubers on Rocket League. He is an entertainer and people watch him because he's funny and intersting.

>The Teacher
The teacher will typically be good enough to be impressive but not as good as the performer. While it is common practice for washed-up performers to become teachers, this usually adds to the joke "if they can't do, they teach," and is not what I mean by being a teacher. A real teacher will have the ability to teach those that seem unteachable. It's as if when they explain something, it finally makes sense to that person. They also tend to have a unique ability in creating an effective working environment.

Considering adding hybrid builds

>The Joker
Performer+Entertainer. Someone who wants to be the very best but couldn't reach it for whatever reason be it lack of dedication, skill, or simply they dont take drawing seriously. Has skill but not enough to the among the "best." Usually ends as caricaturist or making funny cartoons.

>The Producer
Performer+ Teacher
Rare. They're best in their fields but are almost always surpassed by their mentees. See Salieri. Dr. Dre. Eugène Boudin.

>The Meme
Entertainer+ Teacher.
They can sort of teach and sort of draw. And sometimes they cant. No one knows why. See Proko. Ethan Becker.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6467645
Proko and Ethan Becker aren't teacher's, they're washed-up performers as mentioned in "The Teacher" section.

The teaching role is the most slandered because it is often seen as a "fallback" for performers and thus we get really shitty teachers who can draw decently but can't teach for shit--this, by the way, is the majority of /ic/ and precisely why you see people on here saying that /beg/s are retarded or stupid or autistic or whatever. It is simply cope for their inability to teach that causes them to call everyone they can't seem to teach retarded.

In reality, a teacher does not think like this. A teacher self-asses and thinks of a new, creative approach to approaching this new difficulty. As you see in /ic/, these people give up the second someone fails to understand their advice and that is NOT how a real teacher approaches teaching. A teacher does not immediately shift the responsibility to the student, he thinks about what he is saying and analyzes his approach so that it best suits the right audience.

We have to make this distinction otherwise we can consider anyone who started a YouTube channel and made a "How to Draw an Eye" tutorial a teacher when they are simply, and most obviously not a teacher. They are performers that defame the teaching profession with their psuedo-understanding of the subject of drawing. It is absolutely disgusting. My mouth fills up with gravel just thinking of these so-called "teachers."

Say what you will about someone like Sycra but he is one of the very few artists I've encountered who actually hyper-analyze drawing which is why he is able to come up with ideas like "iterative drawing" or his most recent "practice trap" video. Those are oftentimes things that good artists believe or do already but typically do not know how to articulate or teach. Someone like Sycra is able to do explain these concepts more clearly so that those who aren't very good at drawing can begin to do these things as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6467645
In terms of success, I'd say there are some other forms of "the performer" that don't require somebody to be in the top 1%:
>The Specialist
Might not be the most skilled general performer in the world and their skills falter when they try to branch out, but they're quite good at (and dedicated to) their niche, and develop a following as a result. The passion of their fans can help them have some wider degree of success than one would expect.
>The Workhorse
Quality of their product varies - sometimes they do good things, sometimes junk, but they're always doing something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6467645
>The Joker
While Entertainers can be very bad at drawing, they can also be very good at drawing as well but they will never be as good as the performers.

>The Producer
Mentors are NOT teachers. I repeat, mentors are NOT teachers.
When I am talking about Teachers, I am talking about the rare kind of teachers, not some random, ass motherfucker that decides he wants to be a teacher.
Any professional artist can teach another up-and-coming artist a thing or two about what they know. Hell, Kim Jung Gi could've brought a really great artist under his wing and taught that kid everything he knew and even if this kid became really good, that DOES NOT make Kim Jung Gi a teacher in the respectable sense. He is simply a mentor.

Mentors have a lower bar than teachers because you never have to hyper-analyze what you are doing to explain in very specific detail to someone who may need that amount of detail. Mentors will typically ONLY teach those who are ALREADY good at what they do but want to reach the next level. Anyone who is really good at what they do can fill this role. You can be the shittiest teacher alive and still be a mentor and your mentees will still be able to benefit. Bring that same person into a classroom full of beginners and they'll fail to teach even the brightest student in the class.

>The Meme
Those are just washed-up performers as I mentioned previously.

All these other ones mentioned are really just different variations of these.

>draw what you like
This is good advice to keep you motivated, but unless you're one of the lucky ones, this alone won't be enough to improve. You'll need to draw things targeted on improvement, which can still be tangentially related to what you want to draw. As countless stagnant permabeg galleries will attest to, most people aren't lucky enough to simply improve by repeatedly drawing their favorite thing, and at some point they'll have to break out of their comfort zone to avoid making the same errors over and over again.

Yeah, I can understand your dilema. My suggestion is that you go see what the pros in interviews are saying.
When I first started out, I realized that the most logical way to find information would be to reach out to the organizations that literally make a living out of finding the most efficient way from bringing a beggart to a pro.
Which are these?
Private Trade schools for art.
CGMA, Gnomon Workshop, Feng Zhu School, 3Dsense.. etc you name it
These people already wasted countless hours of research on the best path/structure to teach students, so you go snoop their websites, find the syllabus, email them if necessary.

Extract a path out from that, you don't need to listen to a couple faggots in /ic/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
in my experience there are several things that got me to improve really fast:
1. find an artstyle you like and straight up copy it- like idk to go with the most mainstream ones for example and say naruto. it has pretty realistic body proportions and lots of hand movements and toes. you are bound to improve your anatomy with that.
2. even if you arent activly drawing, try study art. watch youtube tutorials or speedpaints. go on pinterest and stuff and make boards of art pieces you like and look at them. try to figure out what the artist did to achieve certain effects. analysing will help you passivly get alot of knowledge.
3. look at 3d pieces /try to learn sculpting like blender. its abit hard at first to get used to but beeing forced to translate shapes and forms into 3d space makes you think of stuff you would have never thought about while just drawing. like i personaly recently found myself struggling with a head as i had to realize the eye corners are a little deeper and the cheeks bump up like a mountain. its something i didnt really think about while drawing and neither focused on when looking at photos or something.
4. mentioned a few times already but try go out of your comfort zone. it will be shit at first 100% but try to not go hard on yourself and even if one study ends up failed, heck you might have ended up nailing an angle of the chin or the shading on a tree bark ended up top this time.


its alot of hard work but everyone learns at a different speed. try to keep the ball rolling. even little sketches a day will come a long way withhin months or weeks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a tough balance. In order to get better at what you want, you need to practice what you want. But you also need to develop a better understanding of art in general to get better at what you want, and a lot of how this is balanced will depend on the person. Some people seem to be able to go "hey, I want to draw cartoons," and just shit out garbage drawings left and right of whatever they want to draw, and in five years they're pro quality. Then you also have the people who go "hey, I want to draw cartoons," and they too shit out drawings left and right of whatever they want to draw, and in ten years they're still cluttering up their DeviantArt gallery with drawings that look maybe just a little bit better than what they started with.
Everybody should do studies, but some people are just better wired for learning by doing than others - what they learn intuitively through repetition and experimentation, others will require knock-them-over-the-head direct studies and explanations to have any hope of incorporating it into their normal work.

Even outside of art, I'm sure most people had one or two subjects in school that they just "got," where they'd read the lesson and after attempting a couple practice problems be able to handily complete any relevant assignment, while their classmates would struggle with homework, consulting study aids, and re-reading notes to develop even a passing comprehension (or more likely rote memorization serving as a rudimentary understanding) of the material.

>>6457517
Lot to work on (though you have a base thats possible to build off of) but a quick one that I think would give you some gains: Id suggest not using thick lines everywhere. Using a thick line on only one side of a form can suggest light coming from the opposite side. More tips in picrel. Even just using thinner lines without worriying about weight will look less flat. Thick lines flatten the work if not used properly. I personally used to use them to cover up my bad, scratchy lines.

>>6457743
I'd like to thank everybody for the critique/comments, but I'm on mobile, so addressing everybody specifically is super hard, so forgive me here plz.

As for your advice on line weight, I specifically used heavy lines to denote limbs, so that when they are above something else, they don't get lost in the details, cuz I've had that happen before, and I know that my demon guy isn't actually very detailed, it's just criss-cross lines for shadow weight, I still felt like those lines could eat up the distinction between limbs. Especially since this guy's prominent trait is having six arms lol.
But I understand what your getting at, as I was about to start experimenting with the white glow/aura/outline I've seen used to do this as well.

And to other guy that said it could use more detail, that notebook is smaller than normal, it's like half, so not much room for details due to medium. But also, there wouldn't be much more detail anyways, as at that point I feel it would drown out the entire piece, and begin to detract from it. The demons initial design was to be skinless AS WELL AS all of the dramatic criss-cross shadows, but it just melded together and became scratch, so I ditched the gore-y aspect and stick to the dramatic shadows (see below).

Other other guy that said better/dynamic poses; yes, I know I've been needing to work on this, as my comfort zone is more for showcasing the character design, rather than telling a visual story, but also, in this case, part of the demons motif/design principle is "dramatic", hence the curtain wings, as well as the six arms to do more acting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6459185
you don't need to worry about that, you will eventually develop your own style as you expand your taste. Your art is almost always just a combination of all your influences, until you get to a level where you naturally start creating your own shorthands. Just make sure you ONLY learn from people who you want to draw like. I learned to hatch from studying R Crumb, and now that I'm good at hatching I realized that all of my lines are very loose which I'm having to unlearn.

fundamentals are Perspective, Anatomy, Value, Color, Environments, and mastery of your medium (Inking technique, oil painting technique, etc)

I really am considering making a total beginners course because so many people here don't seem to understand how to learn or where to start. People scream LOOMIS but honestly I've only ever used loomis for proportions

/highbeg/ you're finding your comfort zone and style, keep trying new things and work on hands/feet and general anatomy. You need a solid (not perfect) foundation before solidifying style.

>>6459067
/midbeg/ You make serviceable lines for painting but as they stand they are not good. you also need more practice on basic anatomy and conveying 3d shapes into 2d space. Perspective also is imperative.

>>6466190
this is pretty bad, unfinished, and pre beg. improvement cannot be reached from further critique of the nothing you made. this looks like you started drawing on a steady diet of appreciating tumblr furry art and that's basically McDonald's for your soul, a cosmic sour milk smell in your psyche. if it's your intention to improve then it's time for a change please continue below. if you are ok stagnating in this skill then stop here

ok here's the plan start copying someone else's work (as exactly as possible) first to get a feel for how much it takes to actually finish something, secondly to learn how they think and solve problems as artists. this will also sharpen your control over your chosen media, which looks like graphite, through goal oriented grinding. pick something here https://www.pinterest.com/pixicurlicues/master-copy-reference/ . This will be extremely difficult for you at first. Do not concern yourself with how, just start making marks on paper to mimic EXACTLY what you SEE, figuring it out through brute force. COPY do not draw in your own style or from memory. Be looking at what your copying 70 percent of the time. DO NOT show anyone your master copies unless they are 100 percent finished and reference the original drawing to see where you made mistakes, take your time and get really bored of it at times, torture yourself and cultivate a god-like attention span. DO NOT concern yourself with outcomes, focus solely on the practice. you'll simply know when it's time to draw ideas of your own using reference material or eventually none at all

disclaimer this is not the only way to learn obviously but you seem like you need some structure outside of scribbling deviant art bullshit. any ifs or but what abouts need to be shut out entirely. any self doubt is completely useless throw it out. I make no promises that any of this will work for you. good luck

>>6463841
I got in the industry by founding my own gaming company with colleagues and being employed there with an artist role. So not really your typical way of getting into the industry, but definitely one with the brightest future I would say. Would recommend over chasing jobs and clients your whole career.
But if you want to get into the industry, don't send the same portfolio to dozens of clients. Tailor it to their needs, show them that you want to do the "dirty" jobs as well. For example, if you want to do concept art, don't just put up flashy images of soldiers (they got enough people who want to do that) but rather lots of concepts for mundane objects that will fill their game world. But really, it depends on what kind of industry you want to get into

For me it wasn't any particular artist but learning just how important it was to see and think with a pencil and ink. I do a lot of thumbnailing in black and white now, so I'll let the shadow shapes guide me as to what should be drawn. I was looking at a Jungle Book art book so that's where served as inspiration for this piece. I do a lot of erasing and let random paint strokes from the positive and negative shapes create new ideas, so sometimes the final image doesn't always come out as planned.

I don't use Twitter or anything like that, I don't even remember how I found Gloss but I do remember that I liked his art immediately.
His construction and foreshortening is rock solid, his anatomy is on point, his figures are dynamic and expressive, his composition is impactful, and his rendering looks really nice on top of all of that. Not to mention that he has a fairly broad range, stylistically. If you check out his visual novel project Sweet Canvas you'll notice that the way that he paints his characters' faces ranges from super abstracted (like Kanna, who's my favorite desu) to more defined and "realistic" (like Io, for instance). I really would have to disagree with his art being "uninspired", Gloss is SOVL as fvck.

posts.com:
>>6459627
You can start right away. Good idea might be to look into charcoal drawing. How I learned rendering and figure draw at the same time.

Buy 24"x18" charcoal paper (or newsprint for figure only but don't render on newsprint). Do figure drawings, one drawing on one page. Use vine charcoal for the under drawing + proportions and measuring, final outlines with 4B, and then you render with 4B, 6B, and vine charcoal. Start out with standing poses, then move on to sitting poses then move on to more and more stuff.

If you already know proportions and just want to render, still good too.

Look up 10-value scale. Look up anatomy of shadows/rendering. Know cast shadow versus form shadow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6462531
>>6459627
Here is the 10-value scale and the shadow anatomy chart I was talking about.

Basic tips for rendering:

-Once you have the figure done and ready to render, start by blocking out the shadow shapes. So it will be either light or dark.

-Next you go back and forth between smudging the soft edged on the form shadows while adding and strengthening the core-shadows.

-Remember that cast shadows have a hard edge, form shadows have a soft edge.

-It's a continuous process, so you will have to keep working it.

-Hatching should start out light. You don't want hatching to look like solid lines.

-In the beginning, you will probably make the shadows too light. Be confident with darks. (Might be more of a traditional issue, good to keep in mind.)

-Go back and add highlights at the end.

-Might be helpful to use toned paper. The paper is your mid-tones around 4-6 on the value chart. Also helps with the highlights at the end and making sure you have a full range of values.

>>6462462
It depends on the amount of control you have, not on the medium. With photoshop, you are using the machine as a tool while doing the bulk of the work yourself. It's just another form of a brush, essentially. With SD, the only thing you control is the prompt you type but you have little control over the actual output besides choosing one that's "good enough". That's why copyright claims over ai artwork keep getting denied on the basis of not having been made by a human and that's also why SD can produce "art" even if you type nothing.

Obviously things get more complicated with people using ai as only part of their work (like for a background) but let's be real, most proompters are interested in quick results, they're not gonna bother with anything non-ai generated anyway

This thread gave me all I needed to know about this board. It's full of people with no talent or abstractist thinking who spend years and years trying to fit into being an artist, Or Illustrator or anything. They work hard or work for a long time to become this thing they want to be however because of this they become cynical, jaded, Do they truly love it? Are they creators, Artists or just people who can draw very well.
They spend a lot of money and time on the BEST NEW equipment thinking it will make them better and it does produce a better product but at the end of the day, there are two realms when it comes to professions like these (To put it simply, Call them abstract and then traditional) and one needs to respect the other whichever they reside in
It's much like /mu/ when you post music.
Your art is awesome OP, whoever this is. The use of white is incredibily impressive . I'm always interested in art that needs to be closely looked at and when I draw, sometimes I try to draw something that is a bit "tricky" to discern what it truly is, Opening the work to multiple interpretations other than the artists.

After a bad salvia trip making me realize that your perception of time is not a constant, but a variable that quite literally depends on the health and functionality of specific area of your brain, it's left me wondering.

How do you perceive time? Just how many days have to pass for you to feel something happened "a while ago"?
To me, around 10 days feel like too old to remember things I did on that day. Seems my "fresh stored memory" lasts about 3 days max.
What about you?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: clock

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465763
You can only remember around 8 things in a week which is why hard working families can move on with their life's like NPCs as you guys would call them, compared to a neet or someone stuck in a mentally ill looop.

But there is a way to remember things long term. You begin by identifying your emotions, and then relating them to your current behaviours & thought processes.
If you're stuck in an endless looop of anxiety, you will never be able to develop memories based on different emotions, because your body will always be in a hormonal fight or flight mode that will prevent you from creating natural neural networks that are unique to you and your emotions.

TL;dr- you're likely anxious & the only way to start creating new emotions is to fix that part of yourself

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

>>6460782
>>6460396
I think people see 'read the sticky' and they get in this /fit/ mindset, that 'right, I'm making a big life change, I need to do X and Y and Z right now all day no cheats', because I think, (which shows you how much I know about that too lol) that if you stay at a certain weight your gains plateau and your muscles don't grow.

Art isn't a muscle. At least not in that regard. It's a skill that you learn because it is enjoyable to learn. Yes you don't want to rest on your laurels, YES, you want to improve, but nobody said you needed to speedrun Loomis, there's no Summoning Salt music intro for /ic/ tourneyfag coming on going 'I got gud in 36.7 seconds, and...' and like you gotta memorize the blook skip.

The value has to be internal on drawing, you gotta practice, but you gotta also draw what you want to draw. I'm drawing fucking gay OCs for a /co/ show, I have no interest in portraits or still lives, I want to draw cartoons that reflect the wacky adventures I write about in my stories. I'm not even set up, this is my digital art's extension right now. Windows 11 Paint, with my right hand that I don't even draw with in not good conditions. This is as far from practice as I can get, /ic/ should rightfully ban my ass for even posting it here on /beg/, to attempt to improve it would be a sisyphean waste of energy, but it was FUN. People get into this 'oh I gotta have the right stuff/it's gotta be a certain perfect level/I'm cringe if I'm not ready' and yeah for the autistic minmax response of an /ic/ thread, sure, respect the board culture, we ARE the Village Green Preservation Society and all but

Dudde, DRAW what you WANT to DRAW, it's healthy. Hell, with the practice you have, you can draw the 'what you want to draw' better. Think about how it can improve too, reflect on your fun art. But have FUN, for God's sake. Art is a time-consuming, energy intense, and expensive hobby. What the fuck are we even doing here, if we're not having fun with it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6463790
That drawing was first outlines using ink and then watercolor on top but play around with the order.

I wouldnt say detail is the strong suit of watercolor. Its good at producing really beautiful glazes and mixes, just delicate saturation. But if you try to wrangle out fine detail you may be fighting against the medium. Thats why I like to do the ink linework too.

Look at accomplished watercolorists working and you will see they look almost careless, with water and paint running everywhere. Only when it starts to dry can you see the skill they applied start to show.

I have many really bad works under my belt to get to the first one where I thought huh, that looks kinda neat

>>6462821
unironically, and this might be really shitty advice so take this with a grain a salt, you should try tracing a bunch of faces and messing around with your traces

chances are the faces will still look like shit even if you trace over it which will obviously imply that they will also look like shit if you copy them aswell.

basically, as you aren’t sure how to stylish certain facial features, you’re always going to end up with shitty faces which is why you need to look at how other artists draw faces to see how to do it right rather than copying exactly what you see

tracing helps you skip that previous step of checking out other artists and allowing yourself to develop your own style without having to deal with proportions
basically you mess with different ways to draw the eyes or nose or lips directly on top of the figure and once you have a style you like then you can copy that and your results will look a lot better

I did what you’re doing now, just copying exactly what I was looking at and didn’t really improve until I started to notice that artists never actually draw exactly what they see, they simply use the photos as a reference on which to fit their own style onto, else you’ll end up with drawings similar to yours

of course take this with a grain of salt but id try it out, just see the result of you tracing the face and see if it’s any better, if it’s not then you’ll realize I might be into something

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6463965
>When is the best time to post your art online for maximum views?
Never. Our posts get uploaded directly into a local server of twitter that no one else can see but you. Same for instagram and all of the other social media sites.

Only way to get your posts seen is by impressing the social media curator with your work, who will then move your posts out of the void server and into the live servers where others can see and interact with your post.

To impress the curator, you have to participate in the tedious process of trial and error in order to test various possible types of content. There’s no telling what will get you through the curator, which is why you must be up to the task of trying over and over until you discover the thing that appeals to the curator.

After you discover that one thing, you’ll think you have the ticket - the key to success. Not so fast. The curator can be quite picky and tends to change his/her taste on a whim, so that same type of post you made that succeeded, likely won’t work again. This leads you inevitably back to testing for appeal against the curator. Keep doing this until it gets through again.

Rinse. Repeat.

Good luck, anon.

With medical bills piling up and her son cold during winter, in desperation she accepts an offer from X to fuck him for money. The sex is degrading and humiliating and she breaks down crying after.

That's the gist of the brief. Who's offering her the money, and what qualities does this person have that would make it an objectively terrible experience for her? E.g. it couldn't be some rich handsome chad as there is the possibility of her ending up enjoying it, since her husband is unable to have sex now. The emphasis is instead to lean on the betrayal, humiliation, degradation, and overwhelming shame/guilt. No pleasure on her part.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6428290
>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas
>also... why does it have regular ship screws?
because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)
>Show pipes or... something to differentiate from regular hull
i think its pretty distinctive from regular battlesip hulls, but i guess it could use more details, proruding pipes arent good for hydro/aerodynamics though., the fuel is highly explosive/hard to obtain aso it wouldnt be smart to have them visible, they are housed behind massive super thick armor plating behind the bublbs under the steering propeller arms, most of the magic is on the inside, like massive stabilising gyroscopes, special pipes and motors for the outside propeller gondolas.etc
also pic relatd are some earlier versions and a regular battleship

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6458574
I was toying around with threads and I got it to look decent, though the perspective is off.
As for the texture, I made Triangle pattern and used the bend tool or w/e in Kirta since I was trying to see how it would look, trying to go for that camo netting pattern thats pretty hard to draw, In the end it was just a test, since I was learning about using textures and what not.
The hard part about the treads is that it it looks off if the perspective is off. It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. I could fix it but I moved on for this until I get some coloring practice in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465289
The vague yet universally agreed upon concept of soul.

On a more technical level, I'd say left has better composition, right one they tried too hard to innovate with a complex perspective, but it just feels like an awkward splash image with no personality. The original one has a lot of momentum, everything is moving to the left or pointed that way, they are going on an adventure VS just doing a cool pose that looks like they just tripped on a rock. Right one also seems like it tried too hard with details. Toriyama's original has a simple style that gets the point across, and any details like the bottom ruffles of hair on the bird thing, its claws, or bulma's hair are deliberate. Compare it to the other, levels of detail are random and everywhere, her face is too convoluted for its size yet the hair is too simple and flat, there's bursts of strong color shapes all over the place (look at the shadows), that are just distracting, makes the image seem cluttered or dirty, best example being the bird's legs. Toriyama's bird legs are very detail, but the shading is simple, and every stroke is purposeful to indicate contour and texture, the new bird's legs are just a clusterfuck of brushstrokes and noise.
Also the washed out colors work better when the background also has that sort of vintage coloring, bright white just makes it look awkward.

And that hat looks so prebeg, I wouldn't be surprised if you told me you drew it in yourself as an edit.

I don't know what you mean when you say "calculate the perspective of a subject", but you should know every body part has it's own perspective. If you're asking about how to place a figure in the environment, the first thing is to be able to plot a perspective grid. Then you can place the feet and knees however you'd like. If you really want to be even more accurate, you need front, top, side views of the figure and environment.

But you don't need any of that, practically speaking. Just wing it

I don't think there is a good way to calculate this. You just have to draw lots of basic forms and do lots of figure drawing. The more boxes you draw, especially from both life and imagination, the better you automatically get at perspective. A perspective grid is just dozens of boxes.

I did them from reference, yes. I drew my bookshelf dozens of times, which has a bunch of boxes stacked within each other, and I got good at relating parallel lines to each other and how to skew them to make the books tilted, etc. I've also done hundreds of boxes from imagination, correcting them when they're skewed.

It's a pain, but if you want to draw environments you have to do this. Good luck

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level
>I came for anime. Why does the image OP say cartoons general?
To distinguish from the anime study thread (janitor supported). Please post your studies there and personal work goes here.

>Community Resources

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I have a problem. I can't learn by reading or watching things. Any information in books and videos just goes over my head, and nothing ends up being processed. I do learn greatly by doing, however. The problem is, I don't get very far with just doing unless I have live feedback and someone personally watching and correcting me (I can't always rely on this since it's a rare thing). But whenever I try to sit down and read something or watch something beneficial, I learn nothing from it even though it is full of valuable information. It gets to the point where I have to read a single paragraph several times just to process what it said, or replay the same parts of the video several times just to get the idea, and it's exhausting. What is going on in my brain and how can I fix this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: notes

posts.com: Try structuring your time and practice every day. You will remember things better when you sleep and review the materials another day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465784
Try just focusing on identifying valuable information, i.e. stuff that you would actually try using or would allow to influence your artwork. Write it down in a notepad document, but don't go overboard; have at most 5 things to try in your 'to-try list.' Your priority is using the things on your list, not trying to find newer information. Remove a thing from that list when you've formed an opinion on it and are done trying it out.

Using new/unlearned information is what will actually help you learn/improve for real, because actually doing things activates so many useful mental processes that are useful for skill learning (building habits of using the information, reflecting on the results that occur from utilizing certain information, forming an opinion of the information, etc.).

tl;dr if you have a hard time processing educational material, you need to be more conscious about actually trying out the new information that you're able to grasp. keep those things in a notepad and be serious about trying them out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Im in the same boat.
I have a comic series that I want to work on, but im not ready to work on it yet because i dont think my skills are there yet. Especially alone you have to be a one man army, with creating characters, backgrounds, story, thumbnails and so on. Its completely intimidating to a complete beg like me and took me a long time to understand where to start.
You gotta start making smaller shitty comics. It's genuinely good advice despite how shotty it is to hear it, because I just want to jump into my dream goal. But it helps, it really does. Im finding that its helping me to write my scripts according to a comic page. Something that I struggled with the longest. And if its total garbage you dont have to show it but you got experience. Plus you do it that way not only do you get a evaluation on what you need to improve your gradually improving your skills. It might take longer then focusing on one skill at a time but itll help.
The story is just important to the comic as the art. Pretty art can only take you so far if the story is trash. There are people more willing to read a ugly comic if the story is more compelling. But theres limits a reader is willing to put up with. You also got to know your target audience or at least know of what you like and want to read. So write stories that you want to put out into the world.
In the end its all trail and error, but if you keep up at it eventually you'll get to your goal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Those are fairly well drawn manga. Both artists had tons of drawing experience before starting their manga. Most people who are going to get that good are too busy drawing and making comics rather than being here, and people who are doing comics like that have no time to post here, so don't worry about it.

Most mangaka do not do extensive series before getting accepted to do one in a manga magazine; usually before this they spend time working on oneshots (short, one-off 30-50 pg comics, and then sending them to editors) and perfecting their drawing skills. Often times they are rejected from editors because their drawings are still too crude, even if their stories are good. During such a time they do grind their art abilities a fair bit. A rough estimate may be you drawing 1-2 30-40pg oneshots per year and spending the rest of your time grinding art skills. I think you understand that it would be a serious mistake for you to not spend some time doing comics. There are things about drawing that you would only learn from drawing comics and you must learn them.

yeah. I was in a similar situation. Went to school for graphic design, did it for about a decade and got burnt out.
Find out what you loved about art to begin with. With me it was cartoons and comics. Jump right in, keep a sketchbook. Look at stuff that inspires you. Learn anything you may have missed in the first place. Keep a schedule. Have fun. It'll all fall into place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464574
Went to a normal stage college for illustration, graduated, and decided to change career paths 2 years after.

My advice: Find other hobbies, if there are things you want to try then try them, don't stress about the art, maybe find some people who are interested in learning to draw and mentor them. Teaching people who weren't interested in making art a profession eventually led me to finding my interest for it again. When I treated their artwork with kindness, honesty, and a gentle touch, perhaps I learned to do the same for myself.

Maybe find a book on basic drawing and slowly work through it.

Don't worry about getting a good as you used to be, I bet you can become even better than you used to be, just like I have, and surprisingly with less effort.

Lastly, it just shouldn't really matter how good your art is anymore. You need to break that career focused mindset. What matters more is being happy with your artistic growth and finding meaning in being an artist. That's a lifelong process and it doesn't mean you need to know the answer, the journey is finding the answer. But that lifelong journey doesn't mean you have to always be creating art no matter what happens. That works for some people but not others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6462859
It's real, but like the general concept of drawing itself, it isn't a single skill and encompasses a wide range of topics that may appear contradictory.
But I wanted to post this because some people are saying that drawing from imagination is pulling from memory, as if you're actively trying to recall an image in your head, and then copying it. Some may have this skill, but that's really not the case for most. That's actually very hard to do, and while trainable, may not be teachable.
When I draw from imagination and I'm using my memory, I'm not remembering a completed image. I'm recalling things like proportions that can be expressed as numbers, and descriptions that can be expressed as text. Text and numbers are abstractions. Abstractions are very easy to remember because they take up far less memory than an image, and are also malleable. So for me, the "drawing from imagination" aspect is the transition of layers of simple descriptions, rules, and proportions to the drawing. It's not about perfect visual memory, at least not in a significant way.
Another example of something that is almost never drawn from visual memory is fabric. Even when you have a reference in front of you, most instructors would tell you not to copy it, but to capture the underlying logic and behavior of fabric. Because fabric is an ever-changing shape, you can't think of it in terms of right or wrong shapes, only if it's behaving believably.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460630
I actualy am learning figure drawing that way. The thing is, you should break down the body into separate parts (head, ribcage, arms, fingers etc) and learn to draw them alone in perspective (create ortho views based on their proportions and rotate them in boxes). Then you learn how to compose each part into a figure (gesture drawing).

I heard about this method from Krenz, and am still learning it. It looks pretty hard at first, but personally its the only way that made sense for me. I find other methods too "feel the form" level of clarity

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I chiefly recommend setting up a nice set of hotkeys. People who only use default hotkeys are insane. People who only click on the toolbar shouldn't be allowed outside.

This is what I use but it's got a few flaws, since I've stapled a few features on instead of refactoring every time
Q - swap FG color w/ transparent (little discussed but highly useful. Do recommend)
W - brush
E - eraser
R - lasso select
T - text/pen toggle
A - shrink brush
S - grow brush
D - delete
F - WTF I don't have anything on F? I gotta fix that.
G - mirror canvas
Z - Zoom out
X - Zoom in
C - Rotate view CCW
V - Rotate view CW

shift+N - new layer
ctrl + E merge down current layer
ctrl + D deselect all

Numbers and function keys are for animating, which most of you prob don't care about and you could figure out what binds you need pretty easily anyway

I've got more on ctrl, shift, etc but forge your own path and bind stuff as you recognize needs arising.

Also speed comes with time. You can maybe do practice oriented around improving your speed once in a while but you can't really rush it. Take your time. Enjoy the process. Take pride in the little achievements. Vibe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Why There Are No Longer Masterpieces
posts.com:
If Bernini had lived today, he would have shown an interest in art at a young age. But, as a child, he would have received no education in art beyond a class per week (or every other week, alternating with music). He would not have had the possibility of joining a guild or workshop, and could not have devoted more than a few hours on weekends to drawing on lined notebook paper and cheap sketchbooks from birthday gifts, because he needed to go to school and learn skills that will allow him to make money as an adult. If he is lucky, the birthday gifts also include a book of art history, but for the most part, his visual diet consists of cartoons and photographs. Only a few of these images are even attempting to be “high art”.

He sees Miyazaki films and feel something profound, which he interprets as a love for anime. His friends mock him for it. He has never entered a cathedral or a gallery and only twice entered an art museum by the time he is 10 years old. Suppose he sets himself right by the end of adolescence – he picked through Wikipedia and Instagram and Pinterest and 4chan and learned that good art exists, and a little bare bones information about how it is made. Suppose he devotes all free time to drawing (against his parents’ better judgement) and develops a portfolio decent enough to be admitted into an atelier.

(will continue)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6457560
But the tuition is too high for a job that will never pay out. This is the first real blow to his dreams, the first wake up call. His parents remind them that his online friends who “drop likes” on his Deviantart posts are not paying customers (at least not for anything more than $5 prints) and break the news to him that his work is not truly remarkable. It’s undeniable – his penwork is untrained and his brushwork is nonexistent, because of course, he’s had no formal help and never chose a particular method to master, always grabbing a bit of this technique and a bit of that from a thousand online sources. He is suicidal for a few weeks (or years) but is sent to CBT therapists who teach him to manage emotions and push forward. Armed with Prozac but with a sense of foreboding still clinging to him, he goes to a regular college (it hardly matters anymore whether it is a state school, Ivy League, or community college) so that he will at least have the certifications necessary to work and hopefully go back to the atelier someday. Bernini chooses to major in Business with a minor in Fine Art, or Graphic Design with a minor in Art History. It’s the best he can do.

(will continue)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6457564
He puts aside artistic endeavors for the next few years, practicing only at an interval of months because the heavy hours needed to save up for an education do not leave time for serious creative work. At around age 30, finally, he finds himself at the atelier of his dreams. It was against his better judgement yet again. He is already married and considering children, and has had to uproot his life and halt his career in order to take off even a year. He will certainly have to return to paying work when this year is over. What kind of art can he possibly produce, even supposing he catches up for his lack of technical training in early life? It will be dull at best, focused on the misery and drudgery of his lived experience and his sense of inadequacy in comparison to past artists who had greater advantages. Or perhaps he will focus on his greatest lived experience - sex with his wife.

This is why the masterpiece hardly exists. When it exists, it is stained with bitterness about the state of the world, with romanticization of past golden ages when art was respected (often straying a little too close to the fascism which also occupied those eras), and with ironic self-referentialism about its own absurdity. It apologizes for itself – or fails to do so and becomes “cringe.”

There are still people who learn traditional art like the masters would, but they are only rich kids, so the 0.1% of humanity just like before. In the modern day there are still rich kids who are educated art at a young age like those before them. There are plenty of people today who can paint on a technical level as past masters, but they themselves are not considered masters because their art is not revolutionary or innovative for the modern time and are rehashes of old periods. The masters of the time weren't only high skilled but actual innovative thinkers who defined art movements and paved the way for history, they did things no one else did and that's why they are masters not just because they knew how to draw and paint well. Although you would like to think you would have a chance in an older time, you would most likely be even more gatekept from art as self-teaching was not as easy and art education was much more exclusive. It's not about living today or back then, it's about whether you're poor or not. Being poor back then would've been way worse and you likely wouldn't be able to even pursue or enjoy art as a hobby like you do today.

I think that’s right, that is one of the parts here that’s taken from my own experience. I’ve been trying to focus on a single method recently, and copy from my favorite artists like Boucher. I definitely know who they are, it’s more that I just haven’t studied them. I don’t know how they do it technically speaking and when I try to create something that looks similar, it doesn’t come out the same. I’m going to an atelier next year and hopefully that will help.
And I choose rococo and surrealism because I love the optimistic love of life, desire, and emotional expression that we see in rococo, but I think that it no longer suites our times on its own. Now that people have delved into psychoanalysis and deconstruction, we are aware that our desires are multilayered and have unconscious, potentially darker elements underneath. So it feels dishonest to just paint people kissing in rose gardens. Instead, it’s better to show the kiss as something symbolic and dreamlike, such as one person’s body merging with another’s, or an infant emerging from a womb. But I still want that same rococo appreciation for desire and for the body as things to be revered and celebrated, full of detail and complexity. Kris Kuksi is one good example, another is Mari Shimizu.

>What kind of art can he possibly produce, even supposing he catches up for his lack of technical training in early life? It will be dull at best, focused on the misery and drudgery of his lived experience and his sense of inadequacy in comparison to past artists who had greater advantages.

Complete nonsense. Some of the greatest art ever made was done as a way to transform and express a great amount of pain.

Making personal art is always better than not making personal art and doing it at 30 or 40 years old is better than not doing it at all.

This western mind virus of the market has infected you. Your post is largely about how it isnt fair that others get this or that or that or that other were lucky and you are not so lucky. Don't get me wrong, i understand how you feel, all artists have these thoughts, but you have to remember that it's just delusion and if you ruminate on this particular delusion too long you'll only condemn yourself for no real reason. Quite often you simply have to work through these things.

On a side note, it's perfectly fine to drop art to start a family; it's a very fulfilling way to live your life and in no way a failure.

you first draw like a master you like while studying specific techniques on the side.
atelier and rococo draw in very different ways from each other. one emphasizes direct and confident drawings, often exaggerated fluid lines, the other is based on blocking in the model in a specific way often using the enveloping method..
painting is more complicated because you would need to figure out some of the typical ways that an artist painted.
great art is a lot more than just suiting our times. you need to make art that can speak to people hundreds of years in the future. there are some works that are known because they tell a narrative about the day, but with so many subcultures in our time, i doubt it could work now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450083
>>6450221
Hi Bridgman-san, you're doing fine, I've been posting along with you in /msg/ this past year. Attached is a page from when I was in the feet section, the memory drawing and corrections are both there, so it's great we both had the idea of correcting the drawing after the fact. The chapter I struggled the most on was the beginning chapter, with all the full figures, but once you start getting into the body parts it goes a lot quicker.

My end goal was to get my drawing EXACTLY like how Bridgman had it, but of course I often fell short. In the beginning, I would stare at the drawing for 15-20 minutes, drawing it in my head over and over again, then I would bang out the sketch really quickly, to not lose any information. When I was doing the full figures in the first chapter, I could only do 1-2 drawings at a time before my brain went caput, but it really does get a lot easier after that.

My one criticism of your process is to use pencil, and then ink on top. imo it's important to give yourself the room to make mistakes. Even all my ballpoint pen sketches I did from manga in /msg/, I used pencil underneath.

About me taking only 1 month to go through Bridgman versus how long you've been doing it, I just chalk that up to the fact that I already had several years of drawing experience before doing Bridgman, so I could do my studies very quickly, and i did it for 8 hours a day, like a maniac. For you, don't worry about how long you're taking, 1-2 hrs a day is plenty to progress. I think you're doing it right, I might've rushed Bridgman, to my own detriment.

Anyways, do your 30 mins of gestures, and your Bridgman, and you'll do fine. However, Bridgman isn't the end, even after finishing it I still feel inadequate. You really will have to study for the rest of your life.

>>6463845
looks good, keep at it but also try to apply what you learn to real bodies and notice the planes they have. you can get in a trap of only copying anatomy books instead of applying what you learned from copying to your own work.

try to use more confident lines instead of "chicken scratching" or petting as much. if you feel like you have to make a bunch of small lines, slow down and make more confident long lines. bridgman was doing his drawings with charcoal on a stick similar to this, possibly even further away. exact details of the lines on the page aren't important, focus on the liveliness of the lines.
https://youtu.be/cIVY5QbDfEY?t=560

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6463867
Thanks anon. Is it better to erase and redo a "confident" line a couple of times? Im not so much scratching as going over two or three times to find the right length/curve/angle. I could erase in between

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6463871
no, don't erase just use less pressure. if you've ever read dodson's keys to drawings he talks about "restating" the line. it's fine to try the line a few times but when you do it too much your ideas get lost in a soup of lines so neither you nor onlookers can tell what you meant. if you do feel you have to practice the line, draw lighter at first or ghost the stroke (mimic the motion but don't place the pencil down). use less pressure and when you're unsure then commit to it. not every line has to be perfect but try to minimize the amount of statements you make. as you practice more you'll figure out what works. this is why it's a good idea to use pen so you're even less tempted to erase or make a mess with a bunch of lines.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6463887
Switched to pen and tried to be concious of my lines. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464515
that's the right mindset to have. much better line quality, just look back at the previous image you posted. it's frustrating at first but as you're noticing, you'll improve your sense of measurement and observation over time where the lines you want appear on the paper more consistently and less by chance.

don't burn yourself out feeling like you have to nail everything perfectly in one line, it's ok to have a few trial and error lines. the biggest thing to be conscious of is your tempo. you probably want to spend more time on the small lines and details and less time on longer lines. this will come intuitively and alternating between the two eventually leads to a flow state. if you're having a bad drawing day your tempo is probably off where you're drawing too fast, too slow, or everything at the same speed.
https://youtu.be/fVY5gla0FNQ?t=131

this is the page i meant from keys to drawing for restating, it's more at the extreme end but should be self-explanatory. restating is more necessary when you're drawing from imagination or sketching complex things that aren't static. you look like you're on a good path and able to be self-reflective which is a step above most artists who want to improve. just don't get stuck copying from books, try to bring these lessons to your own original works. it's a very easy and comfortable trap to get stuck acquiring information and never making your own work.

>>6458087
Don't copy, it becomes a type of crutch, which only limits your ability, whereas learning to do it yourself from scratch, even if your trying to recreate something else, sharpens your abilities and let's you do more.

Also, the flaws of the artist that your copying becomes your own, so instead of improving, your stagnating, or becoming worse.

Also also, work on fundamentals, like anatomy. Everything else gets undermined if the character has uneven arm lengths or something like that, but a strong base can only get better, so don't worry about shading or stuff like that right away, strengthen your anatomy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455543
Have you tried straight line technique?

When doing your under-drawing use thin straight lines. When doing the line work, that's when you curve it. It can help quite a lot with getting proper proportions and that sort of thing.

Also, try starting with one straight line for shoulder to shoulder, and another for the pelvis. These lines will always be at opposing angles. This really helps to get the angles of the gesture right from the start. If you want to go above on this, do a 3d square shape for the rib-cage (more starting from armpit area to bottom of the rib-cage). Then you do a similar 3d square for the pelvis. Know where the horizon line is. Generally you will see the bottom of the rib-cage box, and the top of the pelvis box.

>>6463968
You think we developed Ambient Occlusion for no reason seemingly. We were just trying out cool shit on the computer. We weren't trying to replicate a scenerio present within real world lighting or anything. We were just fucking around and liked the way it looked at the end of the day, so now we use it on anything.
When photons of light fail to reach areas on an object, like its crevices, it creates occlusion shadow. Light bounces off as much as it possibly can before it decays from visibility, when this happens is within the crevices where no amount of ambient bouncing light can reach, within the current lighting scenario. It has nothing to do with subsurface scattering. It is present in every type of material regardless of how rough or smooth, being as we have no infinitely smooth objects, there will always be light decay at some point, thus leading to the presence of occlusion. All without the need to ever mention 3D rendering.
